body_content.explanation: water that flows naturally along a fixed route formed by a channel cut into rock or ground, usually at ground level:
examples: There's a bubbling stream that flows through their property.

body_content.explanation: any current of water or liquid:
examples: the level of cholesterol in your blood stream

body_content.explanation: the direction in which water is moving:
examples: She stopped rowing and let the boat float with the stream.

body_content.explanation: a continuous flow of things or people:
examples: There has been a steady stream of phone calls from worried customers.
I had a constant stream of visitors while I was ill.

body_content.explanation: a group of school students with similar ability who are approximately the same age and are taught together:
examples: I'm in the A stream for maths, and the B stream for English.

body_content.explanation: to flow somewhere or produce liquid, quickly and in large amounts without stopping:
examples: There were tears streaming down his face.
One woman was carried from the scene of the accident with blood streaming from her head.
I've got a terrible cold and my nose has been streaming all week.

body_content.explanation: to move continuously in one direction:
examples: We were all very excited as we streamed out of our final exam.

body_content.explanation: to send or receive sound or video directly over the internet as a continuous flow:
examples: On YouTube, millions of videos are streamed every day.
To pick up this signal, you will need a high-speed internet connection to stream it to your computer.

body_content.explanation: to group and teach together school students with similar abilities who are approximately the same age:
examples: In Britain, we start to stream the children in year 10.
